en: He knew that when he returned to the firehouse, he might wink at himself, a minstrel man, burnt-corked, in the mirror. Later, going to sleep, he would feel the fiery smile still gripped by his face muscles, in the dark. It never went away, that. smile, it never ever went away, as long as he remembered.

vi_translation: He knew that when he returned to the fire station, he might wink at himself, a wandering artist, as black as charred wood, in the mirror. After that, going to sleep, he would feel that fierce smile still held tight by his facial muscles, in the dark. tr_translation: When he returned to the fire station, he knew that he would look in the mirror at his face, which had turned black like a burnt mushroom, and wink at himself. Later, as he fell asleep, he would feel the fiery smile his facial muscles had captured in the dark. As long as he remembered, that smile would never fade or disappear.
es_translation: He knew that, when he returned to the fire station, he would look at himself blinking in the mirror: his face would be that of a minstrel, blackened with smoked cork. Then, when he went to sleep, he would feel the fierce smile still held in the darkness by his facial muscles. That smile never disappeared, it had never disappeared as far back as he could remember.

en: He glanced back at the wall. How like a mirror, too, her face. Impossible; for how many people did you know that refracted your own light to you? People were more often-he searched for a simile, found one in his work-torches, blazing away until they whiffed out. How rarely did other people's faces take of you and throw back to you your own expression, your own innermost trembling thought?

Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "Fahrenheit 451" by Ray Bradbury.

The passage mentions the character Montag, who is the protagonist of the novel, and the theme of people being like torches that burn out, which is a recurring motif in the book. Additionally, the passage's focus on the reflective nature of human faces and the idea of people capturing and reflecting each other's thoughts and emotions also resonates with the novel's exploration
vi_translation: He glanced back at the wall. It was also like a mirror, how similar, her face. Impossible; for how many people do we know who refract our own light back to us? People are often - he searched for a comparison, and found it in his work - like torches, burning until they are completely consumed. How rare it is when someone else's face captures us and reflects back our own expression, our deepest, trembling thoughts?
tr_translation: Montag glanced at the wall again. How much Clarisse's face resembled a mirror. Impossible; how many people do you know who reflect your light back to you? He searched for a metaphor and found one from his own work; people were more like torches; they burned until someone blew them out. How rare it was for other people's faces to take you away from yourself and reflect your own feelings, your deepest trembling thoughts back to you?
es_translation: He looked back at the wall. Her face also resembled a mirror very much. Impossible, how many people were there who refracted one's own light back at them? Generally, people were â€”Montag searched for a simile, found it in his workâ€” like torches, burning until they consumed themselves. How rarely did the faces of other people capture something of yours and return your own expression, your most intimate thoughts!

en: What incredible power of identification the girl had; she was like the eager watcher of a marionette show, anticipating each flicker of an eyelid, each gesture of his hand, each flick of a finger, the moment before it began. How long had they walked together? Three minutes? Five? Yet how large that time seemed now. How immense a figure she was on the stage before him; what a shadow she threw on the wall with her slender body! He felt that if his eye itched, she might blink. And if the muscles of his jaws stretched imperceptibly, she would yawn long before he would.

vi_translation: This girl has an incredible ability to assimilate into the external environment; she is like someone eagerly watching a puppet show, predicting every blink, every movement of his hand, every twitch of a finger, a moment before it begins. How long have they been together? Three minutes? Five? Yet that period now seems so long. How overwhelming her image is on the stage in front of him; and how large her shadow looms on the wall compared to her slender figure! He feels that if his eyes itch, she will blink. And if his jaw muscles stretch ever so slightly, she will yawn before he does.
tr_translation: The girl had an incredible power of description. She looked like someone who enjoyed watching a puppet show. She could predict every twitch of the eyelid, every gesture of the hand, every light touch of the finger before they even started. How long had they been walking together? Three minutes or five minutes? It felt like a very long time to him. In the scene before him, a huge figure had formed; with her slender body, she had cast a large shadow on the wall. Montag felt that if his eye itched, Clarisse would blink her eyes. If his jaw muscles tensed imperceptibly, Clarisse would yawn before him.
es_translation: That girl had an incredible power of identification; she was like the avid spectator of a puppet show, anticipating every blink, every hand movement, every finger twitch, a moment before it happened. How long had they walked together? Three minutes? Five? However, now it seemed like an endless time. What an immense figure she had on the stage that stretched out before his eyes! What a shadow she cast on the wall with her slender body! Montag realized that if his eyes itched, she would blink. And that if the muscles of his jaws tensed imperceptibly, she would yawn long before he did.

en: It was like coming into the cold marbled room of a mausoleum after the moon had set. Complete darkness, not a hint of the silver world outside, the windows tightly shut, the chamber a tomb-world where no sound from the great city could penetrate. The room was not empty.

vi_translation: It was like stepping into a cold marble room of a tomb after the moon had set. Pitch dark, with nothing hinting at the silver world outside, the windows tightly shut, the secluded room belonging to a crypt where no sound from the bustling city outside could penetrate. The room was not empty.
tr_translation: After the moon disappeared, it was like entering the cold marble chamber of a mausoleum. In the completely dark environment, there was no trace of the silver world outside; the windows were so tightly shut that the noise of the big city couldn't penetrate into the room, which was like a tomb. The room was not empty.
es_translation: It was like entering the cold hall of a mausoleum after the moon had set. Complete darkness, not a hint of the silvery outside world; the hermetically sealed windows turned the room into an underworld where no noise from the great city could penetrate. The room was not empty.

en: The room was cold but nonetheless he felt he could not breathe. He did not wish to open the curtains and open the french windows, for he did not want the moon to come into the room. So, with the feeling of a man who will die in the next hour for lack of air,.he felt his way toward his open, separate, and therefore cold bed.

vi_translation: The room was cold, yet he still felt like he couldn't breathe. He didn't want to draw the curtains and open the French windows because he didn't want the moonlight to flood the room. So, with the feeling that he was like someone who would die from lack of air in an hour, he groped his way towards his empty, isolated, and therefore cold bed.
tr_translation: The room was cold, yet Montag felt he couldn't breathe comfortably. He didn't feel like opening the curtains and blinds because he didn't want the moonlight to enter the room. An hour later, feeling like a man who would die from lack of air, he moved towards his open, separate, and therefore cold bed.
es_translation: The room was cool; however, Montag felt that he couldn't breathe. He didn't want to draw the curtains and open the windows, because he didn't want the moon to enter the room. vi_translation: He felt that the stars had crumbled into dust because the sound of the black jets and the light on the ground would cover their dust like a strange kind of snow. That was his foolish thought as he stood there trembling in the dark, letting his bait move, move endlessly.
tr_translation: He felt that with the sound of the black jets, the stars would shatter into dust and that by morning, the whole world would be covered with this dust as if it were some strange mixture. While trembling in the dark with this foolish thought, his lips were constantly moving.

Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "The Master and Margarita" by Mikhail Bulgakov.

Here's my reasoning:

* The passage mentions a character named Clarisse, which is a name that appears in "The Master and Margarita".
* The passage has a surreal and dreamlike quality to it, which is consistent with the tone of "The Master and Margarita".
* The mention of a "Metro" and a "Polic
vi_translation: "But above all," she said, "I like watching people. Sometimes I ride the subway all day just to watch and listen to everyone. I just want to imagine who they are, what they want, where they are going. Sometimes I go to amusement parks and sit on those jet cars when people race around the city at midnight and the police don't bother as long as the cars are insured. As long as everyone has ten thousand dollars in insurance, everyone is happy. Sometimes I hide around and listen on the subway. Or I listen at soda fountains, and you know what?"
tr_translation: â€œBut most of all,â€ said Clarisse, â€œI love watching people. Sometimes I ride the subway all day, looking at them and listening to them. I just want to guess who they are, what they want, and where they are going. Sometimes I go to the amusement park and ride the jet cars at midnight on the outskirts of the city. As long as they are insured, the police don't care much. As long as everyone has a ten-thousand-dollar insurance, everyone is happy with their life. Sometimes I wander and listen to people on the subways. Or I listen at the snack bars, and do you know what?â€
es_translation: But above all â€” Clarisse continued saying â€”, I like to observe people. Sometimes, I spend the whole day in the "Metro," and I watch them and listen to them. I just want to know what they are, what they want, and where they are going. Sometimes, I even go to amusement parks and ride the rocket cars when they go through the outskirts of the city at midnight and the Police don't bother them as long as they are insured. As long as everyone has a ten-thousand insurance, everyone is happy. Sometimes, I sneak in and listen in the "Metro." Or in the cafes. And, you know what?
Sesotho: O ile a re: "Empa ho feta moo, ke rata ho shebella batho. Ka linako tse ling ke palama metro letsatsi lohle mme ke li sheba ebe kea li mamela. Ka linako tse ling ke bile ke ea lirapeng tsa boikhathollo tsa Boithabiso 'me ke palama likoloi tsa jete ha li matha ka bohale ba toropo ka har'a mp'a mpa ea bosiu' me mapolesa ha a tsotelle ha feela ba ntse ba le inshorense. Setswana (Tswana): "Mme," a rialo, "ke rata ho sheba batho. Ka dinako tse dingwe ke ne ke palama baesekele letsatsi lotlhe mme ke ba bona le go ba reetsa. Ke batla fela go itse gore ke mang le gore ba batla eng le gore ba ya kae. Ka dinako tse dingwe ke ne ke ya kwa mafelong a a monate le go palama dikoloi tsa jete fa ba le mo letlhakoreng la toropo bosigogare mme mapodisi ga a tlhokomele fa fela ba ntse ba le mo kotsing. Fa mongwe le mongwe a na le 10 000 000 ya inshorense e e itumedisang. Ka dinako tse dingwe ke ne ke ya go reetsa le go reetsa kwa mafelong a a kwa kgakala. Kana ke utlwa mo diseding tsa sopo, mme o itse eng?"

vi_translation: So it was the very hands that started it all. He felt one hand, then the other, take off his coat and let it drop to the floor. He extended the pants he was wearing into an abyss and let them fall into the darkness. His hands were infected, and soon his arms would be too. He could feel the poison spreading up his wrists, into his elbows and shoulders, then leaping from one shoulder to the other like a spark jumping across a gap. His hands were ravenously hungry. And his eyes began to feel hungry, as if they had to see something, anything, everything.
tr_translation: It was the hand that started everything. First, he noticed one hand, then the other, opening and taking off his coat, and dropping it to the ground. He took off his pants and threw them into the darkness of hell. His hands were infected, and soon it would spread to his arms. He could feel the poison advancing from his wrists to his elbows, to his shoulders, leaping like a spark from one shoulder blade to the other. His hands were monstrously hungry. His gaze was also starting to hunger, as if they had to look at something, anything, everything.

vi_translation: Isn't there an old joke about the wife talking on the phone so much that the desperate husband has to run to the nearest store to call her and ask what's for dinner? Well, why doesn't he just get himself a Shell transmitter and talk to her every night, mumbling, whispering, shouting, screaming, howling. But what would he whisper, what would he howl? What could he say?
tr_translation: There is an old joke; the man's wife talked on the phone so much that the desperate husband ran to the nearest shop and asked his wife over the phone what was for dinner that evening? Well then, why didn't he get a headset and talk to his wife by murmuring, whispering, shouting, and yelling through a radio channel late at night? But what would he whisper, what would he shout? What could he say?
es_translation: Wasn't there an old joke about the woman who talked so much on the phone that her husband, desperate, had to run to the nearest store to call her and ask what was for dinner? Well, then, why didn't he buy himself a radio transmitter and talk to his wife late into the night, murmuring, whispering, shouting, yelling? But, what would he whisper to her, what would he shout? What could he have told her?

en: â€œNumber one: Do you know why books such as this are so important? Because they have quality. And what does the word quality mean? To me it means texture. This book has pores. It has features. This book can go under the microscope. You'd find life under the glass, streaming past in infinite profusion. The more pores, the more truthfully recorded details of life per square inch you can get on a sheet of paper, the more `literary' you are. That's my definition, anyway. Telling detail. Fresh detail. The good writers touch life often. The mediocre ones run a quick hand over her. The bad ones rape her and leave her for the flies.

tr_translation: â€œOne: Do you know why books like this are so important? Because they are of high quality. So, what is the meaning of the word quality? To me, it is texture. This book has pores. It has features. This book can go under a microscope. Under the glass, you find a life passing with infinite abundance. The more pores there are, the more life accurately recorded per square centimeter on a sheet of paper, and the more 'literary' you become. Anyway, that's my definition. To describe the detail. New details. Good writers frequently touch life. Average writers touch it lightly and pass over it. Bad ones rape it and leave its corpse for the flies.
es_translation: Â»First: Do you know why books like this one are so important? Because they have quality. And, what does the word quality mean? To me, it means texture. This book has pores, it has features. This book can be placed under the microscope. Through the lens, you would find life, traces of the past in infinite profusion. The more pores, the more details of life truthfully recorded you can obtain from each sheet of paper, the more "literary" it looks. In any case, that is my definition. Revealing detail. Recent detail. Good sculptors often touch life. The mediocre ones just hurriedly pass their hand over it. The bad ones violate it and leave it useless.
Sesotho: 1 Na ua tseba hore na ke hobane'ng ha libuka tse kang tsena li le bohlokoa hakana? Hobane ba na le boleng. Boleng ba lentsoe bo bolela'ng? Ho 'na, ho bolela ho ba le bo-'m'ae. Buka ena e na le li-pores. E na le likarolo. Buka ena e ka tsamaea ka tlas'a microscope. U ne u tla fumana bophelo tlas'a khalase, phallela nakong e fetileng ka ho se feleng profusion. Ha li-pores tse ngata, lintlha tse ngotsoeng ka 'nete haholoanyane tsa bophelo ka lisekoere u ka fumana ka lakane ea pampiri, ho feta 'bongoli' u leng sona. Ena ke tlhaloso ea ka, leha ho le joalo. Bolella lintlha tse qaqileng. Lintlha tse ncha. Bangoli ba bangata ba tloaetse ho ama bophelo ba bona khafetsa. Li-mediocre li tsamaea ka letsoho la hae ka potlako. Ba mo khathatseha 'me ba mo siea bakeng sa lintsintsi.

Malagasy: Valiny: Fantatrao ve hoe nahoana no tena zava-dehibe ireo boky ireo? Satria manana kalitao izy ireo. Inona no dikan'ny teny hoe toetra? Ho ahy dia midika hoe soratra izany. Ity boky ity dia misy ny pores. Manana ny endri-javatra izy. Ity boky ity dia afaka mandeha eo ambanin'ny mikraoskaopy. Ho hitanao eo ambanin'ny fitaratra ny fiainana, izay mandeha amin'ny alalan'ny fikorisÃ na tsy manam-petra. Arakaraky ny maha-betsaka ny mason-koditra no maha-zava-dehibe kokoa ny antsipirihan'ny fiainana isaky ny santimetatra toradroa izay azonao atao amin'ny taratasy iray, arakaraka ny maha-'ara-bakiteny' anao kokoa. Izany no famaritana, na izany aza. Lazao amin'ny antsipirihany. Antsipiriany vaovao. Matetika, ny mpanoratra tsara dia mifandray amin'ny fiainana. Mihazakazaka haingana eo amboniny ireo olon-dratsy. Ny olon-dratsy dia manolana azy ary mamela azy ho any amin'ny lalitra.

en: A great nuzzling gout of flame leapt out to lap at the books and knock them against the wall. He stepped into the bedroom and fired twice and the twin beds went up in a great simmering whisper, with more heat and passion and light than he would have supposed them to contain. He burnt the bedroom walls and the cosmetics chest because he wanted to change everything, the chairs, the tables, and in the dining-room the silverware and plastic dishes, everything that showed that he had lived here in this empty house with a strange woman who would forget him tomorrow, who had gone and quite forgotten him already, listening to her Seashell radio pour in on her and in on her as she rode across town, alone. And as before, it was good to burn, he felt himself gush out in the fire, snatch, rend, rip in half with flame, and put away the senseless problem. If there was no solution, well then now there was no problem, either. Fire was best for everything!

Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "The Stranger" by Albert Camus. The themes of alienation, absurdity, and the protagonist's desire to destroy the old and start anew seem to match the tone and style of Camus' writing. Additionally, the use of vivid imagery and symbolism, such as the fire and the empty house, also suggests a connection to Camus' literary style.

es: â€”Â¡Fuego! Un chorro llameante saliÃ³ desde la boquilla del aparato y golpeÃ³ los libros contra la pared. Montag entrÃ³ en el dormitorio y disparÃ³ dos veces, y las camas gemelas se volatilizaron exhalando un susurro, con mÃ¡s calor, pasiÃ³n y luz de las que Ã©l habÃ­a supuesto que pudiesen contener. Montag quemÃ³ las paredes del dormitorio, el tocador, porque querÃ­a cambiarlo todo, las sillas, las mesas; y, en el comedor, los platos de plÃ¡stico y de plata, todo lo que indicara que Ã©l habÃ­a vivido allÃ­, en aquella casa vacÃ­a, con una mujer desconocida que maÃ±ana le olvidarÃ­a, que se habÃ­a marchado y le habÃ­a olvidado ya por completo, escuchando su radio auricular mientras atravesaba la ciudad, sola. Y como antes, era bueno quemar. Montag se sintiÃ³ borbotear en las llamas y el insensato problema fue arrebatado, destruido, dividido y ahuyentado. Si no habÃ­a soluciÃ³n... Bueno, en tal caso, tampoco quedarÃ­a problema. Â¡El fuego era lo mejor para todos!
es_results: "Title": Fahrenheit 451, "Author": Ray Bradbury
vi_translation: A stream of fire burst out, rushing to devour the books and slam them against the wall. He stepped into the bedroom and shot fire twice, the double bed immediately burst into flames with a small sizzling sound, with so much heat and passion and light, he had never thought that there could be so much heat and passion and light in them. He burned the bedroom walls, burned the vanity because he wanted to change everything, the chairs, the tables, and in the dining room, he burned the silverware and the plastic plates, everything that showed he had lived here in this empty house with a strange woman who by tomorrow would forget him, the woman who had left and had nearly forgotten him already, listening to the Seashell Radio pouring into her ears, pouring endlessly into her ears as she sat in a car driving across the city, alone. And just like before, burning like this felt so pleasant, he felt himself burst out in the fire, tearing, wrenching, splitting in two with the fire, and completely annihilating that meaningless problem. If there was no solution, then now there was no problem either. Fire is the best for everything!
tr_translation: A large tongue of fire reached out, licking the books and hurling them against the opposite wall. Montag entered the bedroom, fired twice, and the twin beds, with a great hiss, exploded into the air with more heat, anger, and light than he had thought they contained. He burned the walls of the bedroom, the cosmetics box, because he wanted to change everything that showed he had once lived here, in this empty house, with a strange woman who would forget him tomorrow, who had left and probably already started to forget him, who listened to the Seashell in her ear and wandered alone in the city with her radio in her ear: the chairs, the tables, the silverware in the dining room, the plastic dishes. And as before, burning was a beautiful thing, he felt as if he were bursting forth from the fire, away from the grasping, tearing, predatory, and irrational problems. If there was no solution, then it meant there was no problem either. Fire was the best remedy for every problem!â€
es_translation: A blazing jet shot out from the nozzle of the device and struck the books against the wall. Montag entered the bedroom and fired twice, and the twin beds vaporized, exhaling a whisper, with more heat, passion, and light than he had supposed they could contain. Montag burned the bedroom walls, the dresser, because he wanted to change everything, the chairs, the tables; and, in the dining room, the plastic and silver plates, everything that indicated he had lived there, in that empty house, with an unknown woman who would forget him tomorrow, who had already left and completely forgotten him, listening to her ear radio as she crossed the city, alone. And as before, it was good to burn. Montag felt himself bubbling in the flames and the senseless problem was snatched away, destroyed, divided, and driven away. If there was no solution... Well, in that case, there would be no problem either. Fire was the best for everyone!

A kena ka kamoreng ea ho robala 'me a thunya habeli' me betheng ea mafahla e ile ea nyoloha ka har'a sesepa se seholo, ka mocheso le cheseho le khanya ho feta kamoo a neng a ka nahana hore li na le tsona. O chesitse mabota a kamore ea ho robala le sefuba sa litlolo hobane o ne a batla ho fetola ntho e ngoe le e ngoe, litulo, litafole le ka kamoreng ea ho jela lijana tsa silevera le tsa polasetiki, tsohle tse bonts'ang hore o ne a lula mona ntlong ena e se nang letho le mosali ea makatsang ea neng a tla mo lebala hosane, ea neng a tsoile 'me a mo lebala haholo, ea neng a se a ntse a mo lebala,  Ka mor'a moo, ha a ntse a tsamaea ka har'a hae, o ile a tsamaea ka har'a hae a le mong, 'me ka mor'a hae, o ne a ntse a tsamaea ka har'a hae. Joaloka pele, ho ne ho le molemo ho chesa, o ile a ikutloa a phorosela mollong, hloibiloang, rend, rip ka halofo ka lelakabe, 'me a tlosa bothata bo se nang kelello. Haeba ho ne ho se na tharollo, joale ho ne ho se na bothata. Mollo o molemo ka ho fetisisa bakeng sa ntho e 'ngoe le e' ngoe!

Malagasy: Nisy lelafo lehibe iray nitsambikina teo am-pofoan'ireo boky ary nandondona azy ireo teo amin'ny rindrina. Niditra tao amin'ny efitrano fandriana izy ary nitifitra in-droa ary niakatra tao anatin'ny bitsika lehibe ny fandriana kambana, miaraka amin'ny hafanana sy ny fitiavana ary ny hazavana bebe kokoa noho izay noheveriny ho tao anatin'izy ireo. Nodorany ny rindrin'ny efitrano fatoriana sy ny tratran'ny kosmetika satria te-hanova ny zava-drehetra, ny seza, ny latabatra, ary ao amin'ny efitrano fisakafoana ny fitaovana volafotsy sy ny lovia plastika, ny zavatra rehetra izay nampiseho fa nonina teto amin'ity trano foana ity niaraka tamin'ny vehivavy hafahafa izay hanadino azy rahampitso, izay efa lasa ary efa nanadino azy sahady,  Nihaino ny onjam-peony Seashell nirotsaka taminy sy tao aminy rehefa nandeha irery namakivaky ny tanÃ na izy. Ary toy ny teo aloha, tsara ny nandoro azy, nahatsapa ny tenany ho nirehidrehitra tao anaty afo izy, nilentika, nipitika, nandrovitra ny antsasany tamin'ny lelafo, ary nanaisotra ilay olana tsy misy dikany. Raha tsy misy ny vahaolana, dia tsy misy olana ihany koa amin'izao fotoana izao. Ny afo no tsara indrindra ho an'ny zavatra rehetra!

en: And then he came to the parlour where the great idiot monsters lay asleep with their white thoughts and their snowy dreams. And he shot a bolt at each of the three blank walls and the vacuum hissed out at him. The emptiness made an even emptier whistle, a senseless scream. He tried to think about the vacuum upon which the nothingness had performed, but he could not. He held his breath so the vacuum could not get into his lungs. He cut off its terrible emptiness, drew back, and gave the entire room a gift of one huge bright yellow flower of burning. The fire-proof plastic sheath on everything was cut wide and the house began to shudder with flame.

vi_translation: Then he stepped into the living room where the giant ignorant monsters were dozing with pale thoughts and snow-covered dreams. And he fired a stream of flames at each of the three white walls, and the vacuum hissed back at him. The empty space created an even more hollow whistle, a meaningless scream. He tried to think about the vacuum on which the nothingness had just been displayed, but he couldn't. He held his breath so that the vacuum wouldn't enter his lungs. He cut through its terrifying emptiness, stepped back, making the entire room burst into a giant, blazing yellow flower, the fire-resistant plastic on everything tearing apart, and the whole house began to shake from the fire.
tr_translation: Then, he came to the hall where the big, stupid monsters were sleeping with their white thoughts and snowy dreams. He sent a short lightning bolt to each of the three empty walls, and the void hissed back at him. The void had formed a more empty whistle, an illogical scream. He tried to think about the void on which nothingness performed its art, but he couldn't. He held his breath to prevent the void from entering his lungs. He ended the terrible loneliness of the room by stepping back and sending a large, bright yellow fire flower to the entire room. The fire-resistant plastic sheet covering everything tore apart, and the house began to shake in flames.
es_translation: And then, Montag entered the living room, where the stupid monsters lay asleep with their blank thoughts and nebulous dreams. And he launched a volley at each of the three bare walls and the void seemed to hiss against him. The bareness produced a greater hiss, a senseless scream. Montag tried to think of the void upon which nothing had acted, but he couldn't. He held his breath so that the void wouldn't penetrate his lungs. He eliminated that terrible loneliness, stepped back and directed a huge and bright yellowish flame at the whole room. The fireproof plastic cover that was over all the objects disintegrated and the house began to tremble with the flames.

en: He ran steadily for six blocks, in the alley, and then the alley opened out on to a wide empty thoroughfare ten lanes wide. It seemed like a boatless river frozen there in the raw light of the high white arc-lamps; you could drown trying to cross it, he felt; it was too wide, it was too open. It was a vast stage without scenery, inviting him to run across, easily seen in the blazing illumination, easily caught, easily shot down.

vi_translation: He ran evenly along six blocks in the alley until the alley opened up to a wide ten-lane highway. It was like a river without boats, frozen in the harsh light of the glaring white curved lamps hanging high; if he tried to cross, he might sink, he felt; it was too wide, it was too empty. It was a vast stage without scenery, inviting him to run across, easily visible in the bright light, easily caught, easily shot down.
tr_translation: He ran six blocks down the narrow street and then the street opened up into a main avenue, at least ten streets wide and completely empty. Under the harsh light of the high arc lamps, the avenue looked like a frozen, boatless river. It felt to him as if he would drown if he tried to cross it; it was too wide and too open. It was like a large stage without scenery, provoking him to run across it, where he could easily be seen, easily caught, easily shot under the bright light.
es_translation: Montag ran without stopping for six blocks, following the alley. And then, it opened onto a wide avenue, as wide as six lanes. â€œIn the harsh light of the arc lamps, it looked like a river without boats; there was the danger of drowning while trying to cross it,â€ Montag thought. It was too wide, too open. It was a huge stage without scenery, inviting him to run across it. With the bright lighting, it was easy to discover, to reach, to eliminate.

en: What about those lights there? Once you started walking you'd have to gauge how fast those beetles could make it down here. Well, how far was it to the other curb? It seemed like a hundred yards. Probably not a hundred, but figure for that anyway, figure that with him going very slowly, at a nice stroll, it might take as much as thirty seconds, forty seconds to walk all the way. The beetles? Once started, they could leave three blocks behind them in about fifteen seconds. So, even if halfway across he started to run . . . ?

vi_translation: What are those lights? Once we start moving, we have to gauge how quickly those beetle cars can get here. Well, how far is it to the other side of the curb? It seems like it's almost a hundred meters away. Maybe not a hundred, but let's say it is, let's say if you walk very slowly, leisurely, it might take about thirty seconds, forty seconds to cover that distance. Those cars? Once they start, they can cover three blocks in about fifteen seconds- So, what if you start running halfway across...?
tr_translation: What about the lights over there? Once you started walking, you also had to calculate how quickly those bugs could get here. Alright, how far is the opposite sidewalk? It looks about a hundred meters away. Maybe not exactly a hundred, but assume it is, and if you go very slowly, like a leisurely stroll, it would take about thirty seconds, and crossing the whole way would take forty seconds. The bugs? Once they start moving, they leave three blocks behind in about fifteen seconds. So, even if you start running to cross the road and get halfway?
es_translation: What were those lights? Once he started walking, he had to calculate how long it would take for those vehicles to reach him. Well, how far was the other curb? Apparently, about a hundred meters. Probably not a hundred, but better to estimate that, since he walked slowly, with a calm step, and might need thirty seconds, forty seconds to cover the distance. The vehicles? Once in motion, they could cover three blocks in about fifteen seconds. So, even if he started running halfway across...

vi_translation: He walked towards the other side of the sidewalk, with each step he had to remind himself to just keep going, just keep going. en: Would he have time for a speech? As the Hound seized him, in view of ten or twenty or thirty million people, mightn't he sum up his entire life in the last week in one single phrase or a word that would stay with them long after the. Hound had turned, clenching him in its metal-plier jaws, and trotted off in darkness, while the camera remained stationary, watching the creature dwindle in the distance--a splendid fade-out! What could he say in a single word, a few words, that would sear all their faces and wake them up?

es_results:
Based on the passage, I'm going to take a guess that the book is "Fahrenheit 451" by Ray Bradbury.

The passage mentions a "Sabueso" (which translates to "Hound" in English), which is a key element in Bradbury's novel. The Hound is a robotic dog that serves as a symbol of oppression and censorship in the story. The passage also mentions a camera and a focus on a single word or phrase that could leave a lasting impact on
vi_translation: Do you have time to speak? When the Mechanical Dog catches you, in front of twelve to thirty million people, can you sum up your entire life in the past week in a single sentence or a single word that will stay with them long after the Mechanical Dog has turned back, clamped you in its metallic jaws, and leisurely walked away into the darkness, while the camera continues to remain still, observing that creature gradually becoming smaller and smaller in the distance, a beautifully fading scene! What can you say in just one word, a few words, that will scorch their faces and awaken them?
tr_translation: Would he be able to find time to speak? Before the hound grabbed him tightly with its metal-pincer teeth in front of the eyes of ten, twenty, or thirty million people, and pulled him into the darkness â€“magnificently as the screen faded outâ€“ while the camera fixed on him, would he be able to say a single sentence or a word summarizing his entire life or the events of the past week, something they would not forget for a long time? What could he say in a single word, in a few words, that would embarrass them and force them to think.
es_translation: Would he have time to speak when the Hound caught him, in front of ten, twenty, or thirty million people? Could he not summarize what his life had been like during the past week with a single phrase or a word that would stay with them long after the Hound had turned, holding him with its metal jaws, to move away into the darkness, while the camera remained still, focusing on the device that would grow smaller in the distance, to offer a splendid ending? What could he say in a single word, in a few words that would leave a mark on all their faces and make them wake up?

Hound o ne a reteleha, a mo hlakola mehareng ea eona ea tÅ¡epe-plier, 'me a lula a le lefifing, ha kh'amera e lula e eme, e shebile sebopuoa se fokotseha hole- e ntle e ea fela! en: Out of a helicopter glided something that was not machine, not animal, not dead, not alive, glowing with a pale green luminosity. It stood near the smoking ruins of Montag's house and the men brought his discarded flame-thrower to it and put it down under the muzzle of the Hound. There was a whirring, clicking, humming.

vi_translation: From a helicopter emerged something that was not a machine, not an animal, not dead, not alive, glowing a pale green color. It stood near the smoking ruins of Montag's house, and people brought the flamethrower that he had discarded to the Mechanical Hound, placing it under its snout. tr_translation: From the helicopter, something that was not a machine, not an animal, not dead but also not alive, glowing with a faint green light, was being lowered. The Hound stood next to the smoking ruins of Montag's house, and the men brought the flamethrower that Montag had left, placing it under the Hound's nose. A buzz, a click, a whirring sound was heard.
es_translation: From the helicopter emerged something that was not a machine, an animal, something that was neither dead nor alive, something that glowed with a faint greenish luminosity. It remained next to the smoldering ruins of Montag's house, and the men brought his abandoned flamethrower and placed it under the Hound's snout. A hiss, a snort, a sound of gears was heard.

vi_translation: He lay on his back and floated as the suitcase filled with water and sank; the river was gentle and leisurely, drifting away from those who ate breakfast with shadows, lunch with steam, and dinner with smoke. The river was very real; it gently carried him along and ultimately gave him time, the leisure to reflect on this month, this year, and the many years of a lifetime. He listened to his heart beating softly. His thoughts no longer rushed along with his blood.
tr_translation: As the suitcase filled with water and sank, while floating on his back in the water, the river was gentle and lazy, and it was taking him away from the people who ate shadows for breakfast, steam for lunch, and mist for dinner. The river was very real; it relaxed him and finally gave him the opportunity to think about freedom, this month, this year, the years that filled a lifetime. He listened to the decrease in the palpitations in his heart. As the blood in his veins sped up, his thoughts stopped.
es_translation: When the suitcase filled with water and sank, Montag continued floating face up; the river was calm and slow, as he drifted away from the people who ate shadows for breakfast, smoke for lunch, and vapors for dinner. The river was very real, it held him comfortably and gave him time to consider this month, this year, and a whole passage of them. Montag listened to the slow beating of his heart. His thoughts stopped running along with his blood.

en: The innocent man stood bewildered, a cigarette burning in his hand. He stared at the Hound, not knowing what it was. He probably never knew. He glanced up at the sky and the wailing sirens. The cameras rushed down. The Hound leapt up into the air with a rhythm and a sense of timing that was incredibly beautiful. Its needle shot out. It was suspended for a moment in their gaze, as if to give the vast audience time to appreciate everything, the raw look of the victim's face, the empty street, the steel animal a bullet nosing the target.

vi_translation: The innocent man stood there bewildered, holding a half-burnt cigarette. He stared at the Robot Dog, not knowing what it was. Perhaps he would never know. He looked up at the sky, where the sirens were blaring loudly. The camera swooped down. The Robot Dog leaped into the air with an incredibly graceful rhythm and timing. Its needle shot out. The needle hung there for a moment in their gaze, as if to give the large audience enough time to fully grasp everything, the very real expression on the victim's face, the empty street, the steel creature like a bullet sniffing its prey.
tr_translation: The innocent man with a burning cigarette in his hand stood in shock. He looked at the Hound without knowing what was happening. Perhaps he had never known. He looked at the sky and the blaring sirens. The cameras approached him. The Hound leaped into the air with incredible rhythm and timing. Its needle extended, as if it hung in the air for a moment so the audience could see everything: the pained expression on the victim's face, the empty street, the steel animal advancing like a bullet towards its target.
es_translation: The innocent man remained astonished; a cigarette burned in one of his hands. He stood staring at the Hound, not knowing what it was. He probably never came to know. He looked up at the sky and towards the sound of the sirens. The cameras plummeted to the ground. The Hound leaped into the air with a rhythm and precision that were incredibly beautiful. Its needle protruded. It remained still for a moment, as if to give the immense audience time to take it all in: the look of terror on the victim's face, the empty street, the steel animal, like a projectile hitting its target.

Nipoaka ny fanjaitrany. en: â€œThe look of you's enough. You haven't seen yourself in a mirror lately. Beyond that, the city has never cared so much about us to bother with an elaborate chase like this to find us. A few crackpots with verses in their heads can't touch them, and they know it and we know it; everyone knows it. So long as the vast population doesn't wander about quoting the Magna Charta and the Constitution, it's all right. The firemen were enough to check that, now and then. No, the cities don't bother us. And you look like hell.â€

vi_translation: "Just looking at your appearance is enough. You haven't looked in the mirror recently. Besides, this city has never cared about us enough to go through the trouble of an elaborate hunt to find us. A few crazy guys with nothing but poetry in their heads can't touch them, they know that and we know that; everyone knows that. As long as most people aren't going around quoting the Magna Carta or the U.S. Constitution, everything will be fine. Having the firemen occasionally check on that is enough. No, the cities don't care about us. And you, your appearance is really something else."
tr_translation: â€œJust one look at you is enough. Haven't you seen yourself in the mirror lately? Besides, since the city never pays attention to us, it doesn't engage in detailed tracking to find us. A few crackpots wandering around with poems in their heads don't harm them. They know this, we know this, everyone knows this. As long as the majority of the population doesn't walk around quoting the Magna Carta and the Constitution, there's no problem. The firefighters are always enough to keep this in check. No, the cities don't bother us. You also look like a disaster.â€
es_translation: â€”Your appearance is enough. You haven't looked at yourself in a mirror lately. Besides, the city has never cared enough about us to organize a meticulous pursuit like this, in order to find us. A few crazies with verses in their heads can't affect it, and they know it, and so do we. Everyone knows it. As long as the majority of the population isn't going around reciting the Magna Carta and the Constitution, there's no danger. The firefighters were enough to keep this in check, with their sporadic actions. No, the cities don't worry us. And you look devilish.
Sesotho: "Ponahalo ea hau e lekane. Ha ke so bone ntho e tjena ka seiponeng. Ho feta moo, motse ha ho mohla a hlokomela ho hongata hoo ka rona ho khathatseha ka cha elaborate kang ena ho fumana re. Li-crackpots tse 'maloa tse nang le litemana lihloohong tsa bona li ke ke tsa li ama, 'me lia e tseba' me rea e tseba; E mong le e mong o tseba seo. Hafeela batho ba bangata ha ba so ka ba lelera ka ho qotsa Magna Charta le Molao oa Motheo, ho lokile. Ho ne ho e-na le hoo, ho ne ho e-na le hoo, hona joale le ka nako e 'ngoe. Che, litoropo ha li re khathatse. "You Look Like Hell"

es_translation: And on each side of the river, there was a tree of life... with twelve kinds of fruits, yielding its crop every month; and the leaves of the trees were for the healing of the nations.
Sesotho: 'Me ho ne ho e-na le sefate sa bophelo, e leng tse leshome le metso e ea litholoana, 'me o ile a fana ka litholoana tsa sona khoeli le khoeli. Le makhasi a sefate e ne e le bakeng sa pholiso ea lichaba.

Setswana (Tswana): 29Go ne go na le setlhare sa bophelo se se nang ditlhare tse di 12 tsa maungo, mme sa ungwa maungo a sona kgwedi le kgwedi. Mme matlhare a setlhare seo e ne e le go fodisa ditÅ¡haba.
Reo Tahiti (Tahitian): Ia ena dua na wase ni uciwai sa tu kina e dua na vunikau ni bula, ka sa vakasorena e tinikarua na vuana, ka vuataka na vuana ena vula kecega; Ia na rau ni vunikau sa nodra na veivakabulai na veimatanitu.

Malagasy: Ary nisy hazon'aina teo amin'ny andaniny roa amin'ny ony, izay mamoa voa roa ambin'ny folo, ka mamoa isam-bolana; Ary ny ravin'ny hazo dia ho fanasitranana ny firenena.
